passages.text: Reiterate Rating: NEUTRAL | PO: 39.00 AUD | Price: 34.09 A:1%

Rev $178b (+6%) in line with Cons., NPAT $305m (+2%) beat Cons. (+2%). Key points:(1) AUS: Rev +4.3% on improved indexation and private volume growth, but -40bps EBIT margin decline; (2) UK Hosp: Rev +11.9%, volume growth/ mix and operational efficiencies drove +70bps EBIT margin; (3) Elysium: weakness continues, -360bps EBIT margin decline; (4) Europe: France remains challenged, partially offset by Nordics.

No guidance provided. Today's commentary points to a challenging FY26 across all regions. Private hospitals play an important role in our health system and RHC stock is trading cheaply at 21x 12m forward P/E. However, near-term volume and margin challenges persist. Uncertainty on Sante remains. We cut our estimates following today's result (see Exhibit 2). This lowers our 50:50 DCF:P/E derived PO to $39 from $42. Reiterate Neutral on balanced risk-reward.

The usual positive vibes from AUS were absent today with 2H25 EBIT down 4.2% as public hospitals, QLD weather, and digital and data spend dragged on earnings. Despite continued public sector challenges. RHC expects FY26 EBIT growth supported by private hospital activity recovery. We forecast modest EBIT growth (+2%) given Peel contract loss and lower Jondalup pricing. RHC aims to keep digital, and data spend flat in FY26.

Green shoots from UK hospitals with higher NHS volumes and tariff indexation. Elysium occupancy challenges to persist into FY26 and margin improvement initiatives unlikely impact financials for 12-18 months. BofAe Elysium: $17m FY26 EBIT loss (FY25 -$42m).

We await Sante outcome. RHC acknowledged all possibilities were under consideration but provided no colour on options nor decision time frame. Margin expansion remains difficult given French Government funding cuts and modest 0.5% Mar25 tariff increase.

\(+7.9\%\) private hospital revenue increase driven by \(2.7\%\) volume growth and higher indexation. Throughout FY25 RHC negotiated improved revenue indexation with all major PHIs. Admissions saw strong growth across the three core areas: \((1) + 3.2\%\) in Surgical treatments; \((2) + 2.7\%\) in private funding; \((3) + 3.1\%\) in day admissions (day patients now represent \(68.7\%\) of total admissions). RHC reported a \(+300\) bps pcp increase in utilisation, showing strengthening utilisation despite expanded procedural capacity.

AUS U/EBIT grew \(+1.1\%\) . Drag from higher operational costs at Joondalup public hospital and the handover of the Peel Hospital Campus. The new Joondalup public agreement is impacting performance, as the funding mechanism is linked to the WA 'State Price', which has not kept up with cumulative cost inflation. RHC expects a \(- 537m\) impact to EBIT. RHC also flagged longer lengths of stay from more complex cases coming through the public private emergency departments resulting in bed blocks.

RHC saw a \(\) 24m\(increase to the digital and data Opex in FY25, to\) \ \(89m\) ( \(\) 19m\(less than planned), driven by their digital transformation program announced at the FY25 investor day. RHC expects FY26 digital and data spend to be in line with FY25. The program is aimed at improving: (1) productivity through analytics (theatre staffing and utilisation); (2) clinical documentation using AI (3); digitising the patient experience and enabling integrated care; (4) procurement optimisation.

RHC guiding FY26 capex spend to be \(\) 410- 440m\(, including\) \ \(200 - 250m\) for development projects, primarily to expand procedural capacity in major hospital catchments. 21 new theatres are due to open in FY26.

Elysium turnaround protractedElysium saw a \(- 360\) bps EBIT margin decline due to lower occupancy, cost inflation and restructure. \(+14\%\) rev growth primarily driven by \(+8.2\%\) increase in average daily fee and \(+10.3\%\) in specialising revenue. RHC noted continued weakness into 2H25 particularly in Neuro and Rehab and flagged a drop in demand from NHS for acute services. Elysium saw a net increase to beds (despite closing 94 throughout the year), with lower occupancy and opening of new sites contributing to the \(- 360\) bps EBIT margin decline.

Significant uncertainties remain an overhang for Sante regarding private hospital funding and political outlook. FY25 earnings were impacted by a €53 decline in funding. Despite a reduction in general cost inflation, significant potential wage inflation from union pressure in France remains. RHC displayed capital discipline in FY25 reducing Europe capex spend by €24m.
RHC commented they are working through the options of the Sante exit, however did not provide any additional detail into potential options or guide to a timeframe.

Changes to our estimates
Source: BofA Global Research estimates
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH
We make the following changes for FY26:
· AUS: (1) lower FY26 EBITDA margin from 14% to 13.2% reflecting lower margin Joondalup contract following state price funding. We forecast AUS EBIT to grow by 2% in FY26
· UK: (1) increase hospital revenue growth to 10% (from 7%) reflecting higher NHS volumes
· Elysium: (1) Lower EBITDA margin to 6% (from 11%) reflect more challenging trading conditions. We forecast Elysium to generate an EBIT loss of $17m in FY26 (compared to $42m loss in FY25)
· France: (1) Increase revenue growth to 5% (from 3%) but lower EBITDA margin from 13.2% to 12.3% in line with FY25 margins
· Nordics: no changes
· Increase interest expense to $606m given RHC guidance of $600-$620m
· Lower capex to $800m (from $975m) in line with RHC guidance of $755-$835m
Our price objective for RHC of A\\$39/share is based on a blended discounted cash flow and multiple based valuation methodology.

DCF valuation uses a WACC of \(7.3\%\) with a \(1.5\%\) risk free rate and \(7\%\) equity risk premium, and a \(3\%\) terminal growth rate. The multiple based valuation uses a FY25/26e EPS and a P/E multiple of 25x.

Risks to our price objective are declines in private health insurance membership, unfavourable renegotiations with private health insurers, inflation and cost of living risk, and delays in brownfield sites. Positive risks are faster volume recovery than expected, potential acquisitive growth in new markets, or regulatory reform opportunities in existing markets having a materially positive impact on earnings.
